title: Glencore digs in for Rio's coal assets
text:
Ivan Glasenberg's Glencore is understood to back in talks with Rio Tinto about its NSW coal assets. by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Talks between Glencore and Rio Tinto about the Anglo-Australian mining giant's NSW coal assets are back on.
Sources told Street Talk the companies have been back in discussions since it emerged Mick Davis' X2 Resources was also interested in the Hunter Valley thermal coal assets.
The news comes as Rio prepares to unveil its half-year result on Thursday.
X2, advised by Goldman Sachs, has been working on a potential acquisition of Rio's coal mines for months and talks between the companies were reported to be "serious".
But Glencore has long been seen as the natural acquirer of the assets, given it owns neighbouring mines and has canvassed a number of potential deals with Rio in recent years.
Glencore still sees the potential synergies from an acquisition or joint venture. The company's coal chief Peter Freyberg said in June he was in the market for "synergy" deals.
But Glencore has been reluctant to meet Rio's price expectations, which are understood to be north of $3 billion.
X2 is yet to fire a shot after raising US$5.6 billion from investors through Goldman and the Hunter Valley assets are believed to be Davis' primary focus at the moment.
 Elsewhere, Andrew Tremain, Mizuho's head of international acquisition finance, is leaving the firm, according to an email sent to clients and obtained by Street Talk.
Tremain, who spent over eight years with the Japanese bank, is joining Metrics Credit Partners.
